title: Rebecca
body: For @dcompute to review ...

title: Arrays example is very confusing
body: Please check grammar after me :8ball:

title: No convention for saving references to `this`
body:
I see `self`, `_this`, `that`, and a whole bunch of other variable names used to save references to `this`.  It would be nice to standardize on one of these.

I am partial to `self` but would be happy with agreement on anything that's vaguely reasonable (`elephant` is not reasonable, although it would be pretty funny to have elephants all over our codebase).

title: Obect creation vs instance creation !!
body: new Object() is used for creating instance, where "Object" is a JavaScript class and not static object. Where as var object = {} is used to actually create an object. These are two different use cases. There is nothing good or bad about it.

title: Enforce single quotes
body: As described in the [strings](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#strings) section, we want single quotes for all strings. JSHint has a setting to enforce it, which is added by this pull request.

title: Type Coersion was flipped in an example
body: type coersion was accidentally flipped in an example.

title: Investigate Array.push performance
body:
Hi there,

I was surprised to see that `Array.push` was so much slower than direct assignment. The [JSperf link you give](http://jsperf.com/array-direct-assignment-vs-push/5) looks like a good proof of this.

However, the [latest revision of the same bench](http://jsperf.com/array-direct-assignment-vs-push/10), which has much cleaner code, seems to remove this difference, and even show `push` as faster in recent Chrome versions (which I would have spontaneously thought, considering the JIT optimizations that can be done on predictable function calls rather than guessing numerical access).

Are you sure that this recommendation is still to be followed?

All the best,
Matti

title: Fix whitespace one space example
body: Just a small white space fix.

title: Reserved words as property names
body: Note: allowed in ECMAScript 5.

title: Preferred method of boolean casting?
body:
Using logical NOT seems faster on Chrome:

http://jsperf.com/js-convert-boolean/2

though it comes with a loss of code readability.

title: Fixed minor typo
body: pased is now passed

title: jQuery find() convention has bad performance
body:
In the jQuery section, there is this convention:

> Scope jQuery object queries with find. jsPerf

But the jsPerf cited is actually a different test than the example given. The example prefers `$('.sidebar').find('ul')` over `$('.sidebar ul')` and even `$('.sidebar > ul')` however the jsPerf test is not equivalent to the style guide example because it is essentially `$(CACHED_NODE).find('ul')` which means it doesn't need to find the first element.

If you take a look at this modified jsPerf [here](http://jsperf.com/jquery-find-vs-context-sel/16) you will see that 'select and find' actually has nearly as bad as performance as the 'find in context of' style, 90% slower than 'find on cached node'. Cascade and 'parent > child' selector are only 50% and 40% respectively.

Essentially, the citation behind this convention is not applicable.

title: IIFE Parentheses
Update README.md
body: typo in Modules paragraph.

title: jQuery Chaining
body:
The possibility of showing relationships with indents for jQuery object chaining is something that might be worth considering for a style guide.

Blocks at even indent level are all acting on the last selector in the chain, this can help visualize some confusing subselectors. The trailing semicolon might be considered slightly idiosyncratic, but can be thought of similar to a closing bracket.

``` javascript
$('#foo')
  .find('.baz')
    .doSomething()
    .end()
  .find('.moo')
    .doSomethingElse()
;
```

title: Preferred method of integer casting?
body: It's a small thing, but we should probably be consistent here, too. What's the best way to cast to integers? I have the habit of bitshifting by 0 `"15" >> 0`; it's one of the more performant ways to do it, and it's concise, but it also isn't super obvious.

title: Spacing issue within Naming Conventions
Re-aligned variable naming and assignment karma
Jedi Mindtricks
Define globals exposed by Node.js
body: This makes JSHint a lot less noisy when developing for Node.

title: SublimeLinter updates
body: This enforces `camelCase` or `UPPER_CASE_UNDERSCORE` for all variables like mentioned in the README. Constructor functions still require `UpperCase` with the `newcap` setting.

title: Add SublimeLinter settings that match the current JS rules in README.md
body:
For SublimeText users out there, [SublimeLinter](https://github.com/SublimeLinter/SublimeLinter) adds [JSHint](http://www.jshint.com/) support to check your JavaScript files after saving.

Once you install SublimeLinter, in SublimeText go to _Sublime Text 2_ > _Preferences_ > _Package Settings_ > _SublimeLinter_ > _Settings - User_ and copy the contents of SublimeLinter.sublime-settings into that file.

title: Always return as early as possible?
IIFE styles: to bang, or not to bang?
Switched modules to bang-style.
Don't use reserved words for keys ever
body: This one has bitten us in the past. `default` is a reserved word in JavaScript and causes exceptions when used. We shouldn't have an exception to this rule: just don't do it!

title: Switched how methods should be written.
body: Overwriting the prototype makes inheritance impossible: you'll overwrite the base class with your methods. I switched the recommended ways of writing methods so that we don't make it impossible to use inheritance.
